comment: This professor only grades you by 5 things total. You have 4 exam grades and 1 project grade. That being said he gives you all the tools you need to succeed in his classroom. Our class was in person this semester but he recorded EVERY lecture on to teams which allowed students to never fall behind in learning material. Accessible outside of class.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Accessible outside class--Online Savvy

comment: If you're taking this course for a lower class credit (2000 or 1000 course), I suggest maybe looking elsewhere. For fall of 2021, seems to offer sketchy grading system. Also, teaching is unfriendly in some cases. However, if this professor is your only opportunity for this course, please take caution. Lecture heavy and concept heavy per class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Good professor at heart. However, grading is questionable at times and the setup of the class is questionable. And any time a professor is asking you to come on certain days, other than what you signed up for is a red flag (especially Saturday). If you have to take him, stay on him (grading), and his work. Is easily a, take one time only professor.

Took Dr. Chowdhurys Python class my last semester spring 2020. Hes very caring, always ready to explain and accessible outside of class for whatever questions you have. Even during COVID, he was able to adjust how we learned very well. He makes Python easy to understand. I would 100% take his course again.

Goes out of his way to make the class as understandable as possible. Will give example after example and is always willing to re explain anything. Tests are pretty straightforward, as they are mirrored from practice exam problems he gives during lecture. If you only do one thing, just watch and rewatch lectures and the rest will be a breeze.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Chowdhury is found of knowledge when it comes to statistical programming. His statistics classes are a good foundation for data science. I took his R and Python programming classes. He truly cares about his students. His passion for helping students is inspiring. Be prepared to invest time, and this class will pay off eventually.

I took Dr. Chowdhury for both Programming in R and in Python. If you are interested in learning either of them better I would recommend taking his course. He covers a variety of different topics from data analysis to simulation to text mining and does a fantastic job coming up with intuitive questions. He also gives you all the code you will need.

Professor Chowdhury constructed his class in an easy to follow question and answer format that allowed the student to learn R both quickly and effectively. I found him to be both a fair grader and generous with extra credit. I recommend this class to anyone who is serious about entering any big data field.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Dr. Chowdhury is an amazing professor. He's super knowledgable and as long as you put in the work, you'll learn a lot from him. He has high expectations of his students, so don't expect to be spoon-fed information. Be prepared to learn something new each week and at a quick pace. And don't skip class. He gives pop quizzes for bonus points.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: This class should not be underestimated by any student. It requires relentless preparation. Dr. Chowdhurry taught this graduate class really well despite the fact that this is one of the most difficult classes to teach in the master level in the sense that it blends calculus, statistics etc His exam questions are at par with the best in the nation!

I took him for Biostatistics and although the class was difficult content wise especially being a Biology major, you are given all of the code ahead of time, and He does make an effort to try and do practice problems in class, he really does want to see his students succeed.

Despite the previous negative reviews, if you are willing to put in effort, this is a very fair class. There are a few tests that follow a project that is due at the end of the year. Dr. Chowdhury literally goes through the whole project with you and emails you the code. If you practice the project and in-class problems, there is no way to fail.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Sweet guy and he'e kinda cute, but for the love of God I cannot understand what he's saying. He really wants you to understand the material and seems passionate about the stuff, but that does not translate into his teaching. Take someone else if you can

Dr. Chowdhury is knowledgeable about the material but was a poor instructor.  His response to questions was generally, "That is very, very simple" without any elaboration.  Homework was assigned throughout the semester, but he did not grade any of it until the final 2-3 weeks of course, so students received no feedback.

4 grades: 2 exams, 1 big R-code project & attendance. If you know some stats stuff, then you'll only need to worry about R (heavily used). He does have an accent so it can be hard to understand sometimes. He's pretty alright and is helpful outside class. No need for textbook, I didn't even open mine. Also gave me the one point I needed for an A.

He does not teach what will actually be on the tests. He is impossible to understand during his lectures, and to make things worse he has bad hand writing so you can not only get confused by what he is saying but what he is writing.  Do not take him, unless you already know a lot about statistics, he will confuse you

Horrible professor. Avoid him like the plague! He is hard to follow and speaks in a very condescending manner. It's obvious that he understands the material that he is teaching... he just isn't very good at teaching it.

Lecture consisted of reading from the book. Even responses to questions were looked up in the book, with zero additional insight. He would run the code, straight from the book, followed by a comment like "see, it ran" and no additional insight. He consistently berated the class because the content was too easy for grad level.
